As an individual with a disability, Deaf: As an individual with a disability, Deaf person, or a supporter, you can participate in consultations by organizations and businesses who are working on accessibility projects and get paid for this. You can also gain access to resources and training on how to do this.
As you’ve indicated that your organizati: As you’ve indicated that your organization is playing the role of Community Connector, a Regulated Organization may request your services to assist them in connecting to these groups.
As you’ve indicated that your organization is playing the role of Consultation Participant, a Regulated Organization may ask you to represent this group’s point of view in consultations.

Connect members of your community with g: Connect members of your community with governments and businesses who are looking for Consultation Participants. Help them learn how to best work with your community.
Connects the disability and Deaf communi: Connects the disability and Deaf communities and supporters with organizations that are “regulated” or supervised and monitored by the federal government, so that together they can work on accessibility projects, as required by the Accessible Canada Act.

conneting to a Community Connector to he: conneting to a Community Connector to help recruit Consultation Participants.
Consultation Participants are required t: Consultation Participants are required to share their province/territory, their city/town, and whether or not they identify as someone with a disability, Deaf or a supporter. All of the remaining questions are optional. For multiple choice questions, there is an option to select “prefer not to answer”.

Cross disability (includes people with d: Cross disability (includes people with disabilities, Deaf people, and supporters)
Disability is not in the person. It resu: Disability is not in the person. It results when a person’s long-term physical, mental health, developmental, or sensory characteristics differ from society’s norms. When buildings, services, and workplaces are designed for the norm, they often present barriers to a person’s full and equal participation in society. That’s what we mean by disability.

Once individuals agree to work on your p: Once individuals agree to work on your project as Consultation Participants, you can reach out to them directly to coordinate how and when to work together.
Once you confirm your participation for: Once you confirm your participation for an engagement, we share your access needs with the government or business that you are working with. This will help them seek out the appropriate service providers to meet your access need(s).

Once you confirm your participation for an engagement, we will share your preferred contact method and your contact information with the government or business. This information enables them to contact you to discuss the details of your participation.
Once you create your page, organizations: Once you create your page, organizations can find you and ask you to consult on their projects.
Once you follow some organizations that: Once you follow some organizations that you’re interested in, you will be notified whenever they begin a consultation process.
Once you publish your page, other users: Once you publish your page, other users on this website can access your page.
Once you publish your project, others ca: Once you publish your project, others can find it.

These are the seven areas listed within: These are the seven areas listed within the Accessible Canada Act. By law, Federally Regulated Organizations must ensure these areas are accessible.
These are the seven areas listed within the Accessible Canada Act. Federally regulated organizations must work to improve their accessibility in all of these areas.

These organizations, coalitions, cross-d: These organizations, coalitions, cross-disability or umbrella groups are made up of, and controlled by, persons with disabilities, Deaf persons, and/or their family members. These organizations were created to advance and defend the rights of persons with disabilities.
These organizations have constituencies: These organizations have constituencies which include persons with disabilities, Deaf persons, and family members. Disability and Deaf services are not the primary mandate of these organizations.
These organizations provide services to: These organizations provide services to people with disabilities and/or Deaf persons, advocate on their behalf, undertake research, provide training and awareness building, and/or deliver accessibility services.

This includes projects by Regulated Orga: This includes projects by Regulated Organizations and Community Organizations.
This includes reports, contracts, or any: This includes reports, contracts, or anything else you would like Consultation Participants to be able to access.
This information is a part of your publi: This information is a part of your public profile that you can publish and share with other members of the website, including governments and businesses. This provides an overview to others about who you are.
This information is used to tell regulat: This information is used to tell regulated organizations if you have any special interests. This entire page is optional.
This information will help governments a: This information will help governments and businesses communicate and work with you in a format that is accessible to you.
This information will help potential Con: This information will help potential Consultation Participants on the website like individuals with disabilities, and individuals who are Deaf learn about your organization.
This is also the email you use to sign i: This is also the email you use to sign in to this account. If you change this, you are also changing your sign in email.
This is for federally regulated organiza: This is for federally regulated organizations under the Accessible Canada Act.
This is for individuals with disabilitie: This is for individuals with disabilities or Deaf individuals, their supporters, and those wishing to offer accessibility consulting and community connection services.
This is the email address you will use t: This is the email address you will use to sign in to The Accessibility Exchange.
This is the email you use to sign into t: This is the email you use to sign into the website.
This is the ideal number of participants: This is the ideal number of participants you would like to have for this engagement.
This is the name that will be displayed: This is the name that will be displayed on your page. This does not have to be your legal name.
This is the name that will be displayed on your project page.
This is the name that will show up publi: This is the name that will show up publicly on your page.
This organization has people on staff wh: This organization has people on staff who have lived experience of the communities they :represent_or_serve_and_support.
This site is for three kinds of users. S: This site is for three kinds of users. Select an option below to learn more.
This user already belongs to this team.
This website was made in partnership wit: This website was made in partnership with members and organizations from the disability and Deaf communities, supporters, and members from Federally Regulated Organizations.
This will help governments and businesse: This will help governments and businesses communicate and work with you in a format that is accessible to you.
This will help you get paid in the way t: This will help you get paid in the way that you want.
Throughout this page, you can choose whe: Throughout this page, you can choose whether you would like notifications to be sent through the website or by contacting the project team contact for that specific project directly. You can edit this in each individual project page.
Throughout this page, you can chose whet: Throughout this page, you can chose whether you would like notifications to be sent through the website or by contacting :contact_person directly.

We have a hub of resources and trainings: We have a hub of resources and trainings. The materials can help you and your team deepen your understanding of disability and inclusion.
We will always notify you when you are i: We will always notify you when you are invited to engagements by contacting you or your support person.
We will ask you about what is the best w: We will ask you about what is the best way to contact you, and your contact information. We will also ask you about whether you have a preference for either in-person or virtual meetings.
We will ask you about what your access n: We will ask you about what your access needs are to participate in either an in-person meeting or virtual meeting. We also ask whether you have a preference for either in-person or virtual meetings.
We will ask you about whether you have a: We will ask you about whether you have a preference for either in-person or virtual meetings. We will also ask you how you would like us to contact you, and for your contact information.

When Federally Regulated Organizations u: When Federally Regulated Organizations use the matching service to find a group of Consultation Participants, The Accessibility Exchange will create a diverse group of participants in terms of being disabled, Deaf, and other identities. This diversity can maximize the number of perspectives which can be represented.

You can communicate directly with the bu: You can communicate directly with the business or government to figure out when and how to work on their accessibility project. You will be paid for your work.

This can be your organization’s Accessibility Plan or Report (as required under the Accessible Canada Act), or getting feedback on your customer service or accessibility in your workplace.
